questions.question_text: Which LISP infrastructure device provides connectivity between non-LISP sites and LISP sites by receiving non-LISP traffic with a LISP site destination?

comments.content:
Further simplified:
PITRs are for Non-LISP > LISP
PETRs are for LISP > Non-LISP

Always remember who is performing encapsulation and de-encapsulation. xITRs always encapsulate, whether [FROM] a LISP-RLOC or Non-LISP Site; while xETRs always de-encapsulate, whether [TO] a LISP-RLOC or Non-LISP Site.

discussion.content:
A is correct
PITRs are for non-LISP sites that send traffic to EID destinations.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

PITR (Proxy Ingress Tunnel Router)
PETR (Proxy Egress Tunnel Router)
pitr is ingress so is recieving the egress is sending out the other side of the device

"A PITR is a LISP Infrastructure device that provides connectivity between non-LISP sites and LISP sites by attracting non-LISP traffic destined to LISP sites and encapsulating this traffic to ETRs devices deployed at LISP sites. "

Selected Answer: A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Data_Center/DCI/5-0/LISPmobility/DCI_LISP_Host_Mobility/LISPmobile_2.html#:~:text=%E2%80%93%20Proxy%20ITR%20(PITR)%3A%20A,devices%20deployed%20at%20LISP%20sites.

" An ITR is a LISP Site edge device that receives packets from site-facing interfaces (internal hosts) and encapsulates them to remote LISP sites, or natively forwards them to non-LISP sites. "

Selected Answer: A
Proxy ITR (PITR): PITR is a LISP infrastructure device that provides connectivity between non-LISP sites and LISP sites by attracting non-LISP traffic that is destined to LISP sites and encapsulating this traffic to devices of ETR that are deployed at LISP sites.

comments.content:
As rezavage wrote:
PITRs are for Non-LISP --> LISP
PETRs are for LISP --> Non-LISP

Proxy ETR = PETR

discussion.content:
Q95. Which LISP component is required for a LISP site to communicate with a non-LISP site?

 A. Proxy ITR
 B. ITR
 C. ETR
 D. Proxy ETR

^^^ How is the answer to this one D - Proxy ETR?

Selected Answer: A
voting. provided answer is correct
Correct

choices.C: runs directly on a physical server and includes its own operating system
choices.A: installed as an application on an already installed operating system
choices.B: also referred to as a “bare metal hypervisor” because it sits directly on the physical server

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
https://www.hitechnectar.com/blogs/hypervisor-type-1-vs-type-2/

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer

choices.C: Problems in the base operating system can affect the entire system.
choices.D: It is installed on an operating system and supports other operating systems above it.
choices.A: It is referred to as a hosted hypervisor.
choices.B: It is completely independent of the operating system.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B seems to be the closest that makes sense, even though do not like the wording.

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of a Type 1 hypervisor?

discussion.content: Looks like Dipole to me.

comments.content:
And it is, because it's categorized as a common type of omnidirectional antenna:

https://study-ccnp.com/directional-antenna-vs-omnidirectional-antenna/
Yes, also see question 183, same characteristics.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
See the patterns this way:

Elevation pattern: You are seeing the propagation standing in front of the antenna in a vertical perspective.

Azimuth pattern: You are seeing the propagation from above the antena in a horizontal perspective.

Combine both views and you rarely miss.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A

relax , all answers are wrong . 
When advertising a network in bgp syntax is: #(router-bgp)# network x.x.x.x mask y.y.y.y

discussion.content: Unless I am missing something here, none of these are right. Let me know if I am missing something.

The diagram is wrong.

Router A resides in AS 65001.
Router B resides in AS 65002.

Question: An engineer must configure an eBGP neighborship to Router B on Router A. The network that is connected to GO/1 on Router A must be advertised to Router B. Which configuration should be applied?

Answer is D:
router bgp 65001
neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65002
network 10.0.2.0 255.255.255.0

Selected Answer: D
I am sure completely all options are wrong because we should login in router A and type the following commands for advertise the mentioned network:
R-A(config)# router bgp 65002
R-A(config-router)# neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65001
R-A(config-router)# network 10.0.2.0 mask 255.255.255.0
R-A(config-router)# exit

Selected Answer: B
For any future pass byers, please refer to KZM post below:
"
 KZM 11 months, 2 weeks ago
Router A (ASN: 65001) "10.0.1.1" <-----------------> "10.0.1.2" Router B (ASN: 65002)
Router A G0/1 "10.0.2.1/24"


Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must configure an eBGP neighborship to Router B on Router A. The network
that is connected to G0/1 on Router A must be advertised to Router B. Which configuration should be applied?
A. router bgp 65001
neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65002
network 10.0.1.0 255.255.255.0
B. router bgp 65001
neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65002
network 10.0.2.0 255.255.255.0
C. router bgp 65001
neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65002
redistribute static
D. router bgp 65002
neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65002
network 10.0.2.0 255.255.255.0
Answer: C
https://cloudeducation.com.hk/exam/350-401.pdf

Selected Answer: B
The command should like that;
router bgp 65001
neighbor 10.0.1.2 remote-as 65002
network 10.0.2.0 mask 255.255.255.0

If "mask" is missing in the network command, option D is incorrect.
If it is not a typo, the answer may be B.

comments.content:
remote as IP is wrong.
D is not correct either

The AS numbers are clearly inverted. 
Router A belongs to AS 65001 and Router B belongs to AS 65002.
Considering that, the best option is D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The wording of the question is mising. It should have been as follows:
"An engineer must configure an eBGP neighborship to Router B on Router A. The network that is connected to G0/1 on Router A must be advertised to Router B. Which configuration should be applied?"
That makes D the correct answer, even though the keyword "mask" is missing from the network statement.
